hero.title: Q and A
hero.subtitle: This page organizes the most common challenges and criticisms surrounding breeding, and presents Ratopia Rattery’s response framework. I do not avoid the inherent risks and power dynamics involved in breeding, nor do I accept one-line judgments that attempt to define all breeding as the same. The core of the discussion is not whether breeding exists, but whether there are verifiable boundaries, constraints, and long-term responsibility—and whether someone is willing to bear the consequences when choices are made.

body.text: 1. People who truly love animals would never breed them; breeding is exploitation and oppression of reproductive ability

Breeding does involve the use of an animal’s reproductive capacity, and it carries real risks of abuse and instrumentalization. This cannot be denied and should not be glossed over. However, equating all breeding with “exploitation and oppression” is logically absolute and overly simplistic.

The key issue is not whether breeding occurs, but whether it is conducted with animal welfare as its premise, and whether clear boundaries and constraints exist. If any use of reproductive capacity is defined as oppression, then nearly all forms of human–animal interaction would fall under condemnation, including scientific conservation, endangered species protection, and strictly regulated companion animal breeding. This stance can be ethically coherent, but it represents a radical anti-breeding position rather than a generally applicable judgment of real-world practices.

A more rigorous formulation would be: people who truly love animals do not consume or exhaust their reproductive capacity without limits or constraints for human goals. Once breeding detaches from health, welfare, and long-term responsibility, it becomes exploitation. But not all breeding is, by definition, oppression. Drawing clear boundaries is more valuable than blanket denial.
2. Backyard breeding, small-scale home breeding, breeding mills, and so-called ethical breeders are essentially the same

In reality, there are indeed many cases where people claim the label of “ethical breeding” while operating no differently from backyard breeders. Vigilance toward such behavior is entirely justified. However, concluding from this that all ethical breeding is merely a façade is a conceptual error.

The distinction lies not in labels, but in whether real structures and constraints exist. If a breeder maintains clear and verifiable limits on breeding frequency, provides protection and retirement plans for breeding females, takes a conservative approach to genetic risk, refuses high-risk transport, and assumes long-term follow-up and take-back responsibility,

then regardless of scale, there is a substantive difference from backyard breeding or breeding mills driven solely by sales. Conversely, if such constraints are absent and “ethics” exists only as rhetoric or persona, criticism of moral posturing is entirely warranted.

In other words, the problem is not whether ethical breeders can exist, but whether self-claimed ethics are allowed to replace structural constraints. Denying the former is lazy; denying the latter is necessary.
3. My pet belongs to me; I should be free to do whatever I want, and others have no right to interfere
This is a common and important position, as it touches directly on the relationship between ownership and ethical responsibility.

From a legal perspective, in most existing systems pets are considered property, and owners enjoy broad rights of disposition. But legal boundaries do not automatically equate to ethical legitimacy. Society’s condemnation of animal abuse or extreme neglect rests precisely on a shared recognition that when the subject is a sentient being capable of suffering, “it belongs to me” is not a sufficient justification.

Breeding practices, health management, and welfare conditions are not purely private matters. They generate external consequences through disease transmission, genetic risk diffusion, rising abandonment rates, and market signaling, affecting other animals, other keepers, and the broader ecosystem. When actions produce clear public consequences, discussion and intervention cease to be “meddling” and become part of public ethics.

Owners do have broad decision-making authority, but this authority is not absolute. It is conditioned on avoiding unnecessary suffering to animals and significant harm to the public environment. This does not negate ownership; it affirms that rights and responsibilities are inseparable.
4. Why do you keep and breed fancy rats?
This is a question frequently asked by friends and family. Below is my answer.

I am deeply interested in the genetics of fancy rats—not only the genes that determine color and markings. I enjoy setting goals for myself and, through extensive work across many generations, watching my bloodlines gradually improve and approach my ideals.

Of course, perfection does not exist. But every carefully considered pairing brings me a step closer to what I define as “better.” Seeing the quality of my rats improve generation by generation, with increasingly stable bloodlines, brings an incomparable sense of fulfillment. This is the driving force behind my commitment.

I keep and breed fancy rats for myself, or rather, to become who I want to be.

I do not breed to chase sales, satisfy market demand, or shorten adopters’ waiting time. As a result, those who wish to adopt from my rattery may sometimes need to wait before an opportunity becomes available.

I refuse to place my rats with impulse keepers, and I refuse to provide rats intended as gifts.

Keeping a rat is, without question, a commitment of at least two years. In this contract, the rat is the true primary party. Even if the rat is acquired for a child, the responsibility of care lies with the parents. In reality, most children lose interest in a new pet within weeks, and parents must recognize that once an animal is purchased or adopted, the duty of care belongs to them—not the child.

Therefore, adoptions must be conducted by parents themselves, and adopters must be capable of providing detailed care and covering necessary veterinary expenses.

I am aware that this stance will attract criticism, but I will not change it. This approach yields the most meaningful long-term feedback, giving me sufficient data and conditions to refine my breeding plans.

You may have specific preferences when adopting, and I support reasonable expectations for the companion who will accompany you. When these rats meet your expectations in terms of color, genetics, or appearance, it often means you will feel more responsible toward them. However, you must understand certain facts: many so-called “rare genes,” “rare markings,” or “rare colors” were first discovered worldwide in feeder rat populations. Whenever a new trait appears, demand surges—people say, “I want that new color.”

Unfortunately, many individuals then label themselves as “home breeders” or “ethical breeders,” and once they obtain a new trait, they mass-produce and sell for profit. The result is large numbers of rats with health problems being bred indiscriminately. These traits spread without control, quality declines, and the health and temperament of the lines deteriorate rather than improve.

China’s fancy rat market once experienced a wave of megacolon cases, largely driven by the pursuit of special traits combined with the reckless expansion of such breeders. It was a tragedy produced by mutual reinforcement of demand and irresponsible supply, leading to irreversible losses.

I will never allow a rat to leave my rattery if I have any doubt about its health or temperament. The purpose of this rattery is to improve the overall quality of fancy rats, not to indiscriminately produce more sick or aggressive individuals—regardless of whether their eventual fate is neglect, abandonment, or rescue by well-meaning keepers.

My bloodlines will inevitably encounter problems, and I am willing to address them. I am also committed to maintaining active communication with adopters, as their feedback is critically important to me.
